name: Fernando Alonso
religion: Alonso was raised a Catholic but is now an atheist.
politicalViews: Alonso isn't political, but he's sensitive to the plight of the people of Southern Europe's debt-racked countries.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Fernando Alonso, full name Fernando Alonso Díaz, was born and raised in Oviedo, Asturias, Spain.
Alonso is listed on various websites as a Catholic.
I'd feel safe to say that he was raised a Catholic considering Spain is a predominantly Catholic nation and he attended a school growing up called the Holy Guardian Angel Primary School.

content.sourceTitle: Ferrari makes me turn into a child
content.text: But he's certainly not a Catholic anymore. Once during an interview, Alonso was asked directly if he believes in God. He simply said, "no."
I don't have any relationship with God and I've never wanted it. I don't believe in fate or in any superior entity: if a plane crashes and people die, it's not because Heaven said so.

content.sourceTitle: Ferrari makes me turn into a child
content.text: He is a bit superstitious when it comes to numbers though. Because he won his first kart world championship at the age of 14, Alonso believes that a mathematical equation involving the number on his helmet, his hotel room number and the number of cars on the starting grid must equal 14.
Perhaps we could call him a numerologist. But in conventional terms, he's definitely an atheist.
Alonso has repeatedly confirmed that he's not interested in politics, once saying:

content.sourceTitle: Fernando Alonso: "I don't think I am good at politics…"
content.text: I don't think I am good at politics, I just drive the car.

But his home country, along with much of southern Europe including Portugal, Italy and Greece have spent the last several years gripped with fiscal uncertainty, faced with economic collapse and shouldered with the guilt that they might be responsible for the downfall of the Eurozone. Perhaps Alonso's most political statement was to lift the spirits and pride of those countries. He said after winning a race:

content.sourceTitle: F1 Fernando Alonso: "I don't really know politics but…"
content.text: I don't really know politics but it is true that the situation is not great in Spain but a Spanish driver in an Italian car, designed by a Greek man is good to win here.
